question_text:
A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain, tingling, and numbness in his right hand that started 3 months ago. The symptoms are worse at night and frequently wake him up. The symptoms can be relieved by shaking his hands but soon recur. He reports weakness of his right hand, especially when grasping objects. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications are metformin and sitagliptin. Four months ago he went on a camping trip. He has been working as a landscape gardener for 8 years. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows reproduction of his symptoms when his right hand is held above his head for 2 minutes. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.2 g/dL

Leukocyte count
7600/mm^3

Hemoglobin A_1C

6.3%

Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
13 mm/h

Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain, tingling, and numbness in his right hand that started 3 months ago. The symptoms are worse at night and frequently wake him up. The symptoms can be relieved by shaking his hands but soon recur. He reports weakness of his right hand, especially when grasping objects. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications are metformin and sitagliptin. Four months ago he went on a camping trip. He has been working as a landscape gardener for 8 years. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows reproduction of his symptoms when his right hand is held above his head for 2 minutes. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL Leukocyte count 7600/mm3 Hemoglobin A1C 6.3% Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 13 mm/h Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: Risk factors for this patient's condition include diabetes mellitus with peripheral polyneuropathy, pregnancy, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and rheumatoid arthritis.
learning_objective: Recognize carpal tunnel syndrome, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: ELISA for Borrelia burgdorferi antibodies is a serologic test for diagnosing Lyme disease. Although Lyme disease may manifest with peripheral neuropathy, this patient has not experienced the typical erythema migrans and there is no history of a tick bite. Although these factors are not always positive in Lyme disease, neurologic manifestations associated with the condition would not be exacerbated by certain movements. Lastly, Lyme disease is typically associated with an elevated ESR and sometimes elevated leukocytes, but this patient's values are normal.

A CT scan of the cervical spine would be indicated for suspected cervical radiculopathy (e.g., caused by a herniated disc or a tumor). Cervical radiculopathy can manifest with pain, tingling, and numbness of the hands as well, but it usually also causes neck and shoulder pain, which this patient lacks. Additionally, exacerbation during the night or during activities involving the hands (e.g., grasping objects) is not consistent with cervical radiculopathy, which is rather exacerbated by neck extension.

Nerve conduction studies confirm suspected carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). This patient's history of hand paresthesia and pain exacerbated at night (due to reduced circulation and muscle movements during REM sleep) and while grasping objects is typical for CTS. Additionally, his occupation as a landscape gardener is a risk factor since CTS is associated with manual work leading to repetitive and forceful flexion and extension of the wrist. Provocative tests used in the diagnosis of CTS include Phalen, Tinel, and, as seen here, hand elevation tests.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) could be indicated for suspected several CNS disorders, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Although MS may manifest with peripheral paresthesia, it is usually associated with several other manifestations such as vision loss or ataxia. Additionally, as the defect is located in the central nervous system (not the periphery), symptoms would not worsen when the patient raises his hand.

Doppler ultrasound is an important procedure for evaluating peripheral artery disease (PAD). This condition may manifest with claudication, weakness, and numbness of the affected extremity, which are symptoms that this patient has. The patient also has a history of diabetes mellitus, which may predispose him to PAD. However, the condition most commonly affects the legs and very rarely the hands. Furthermore, this patient's history (i.e., manual worker with symptoms that exacerbate during the night and while grabbing objects) is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

question_text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after he sustained an injury to his right hand while playing basketball. The ball hit his right index finger with force and he is now unable to lift the end of the finger. Examination shows a right index finger flexed at the distal interphalangeal joint and inability to actively extend the distal phalanx; range of motion is limited by pain. There is an extension deficit of 10°. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the hand shows no fractures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 2 hours after he sustained an injury to his right hand while playing basketball. The ball hit his right index finger with force and he is now unable to lift the end of the finger. Examination shows a right index finger flexed at the distal interphalangeal joint and inability to actively extend the distal phalanx; range of motion is limited by pain. There is an extension deficit of 10°. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the hand shows no fractures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The flexed distal interphalangeal joint with the inability to actively extend the distal phalanx after direct trauma to the finger suggests an extensor tendon injury (mallet finger).
learning_objective: Recognize mallet finger, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: In uncomplicated extensor digitorum tendon injuries (no associated displaced fractures, extension deficit < 45°), a stack splint is used to stabilize the joint for 6–8 weeks in slight hyperextension in order to achieve a close approximation of the tendon ends and full recovery. When applying splints to areas with bony protuberances, as in this case, excessive direct pressure from the splint must be avoided. Continuous pressure can lead to skin necrosis and subsequent healing disorders and infections.

images.title: Mallet finger
images.description: Right middle finger with extended PIP and flexed DIP jointsThis condition results from sudden forced hyperflexion of the DIP joint while the digit is extended (particularly common in sports such as basketball and baseball), which causes rupture or avulsion of the extensor digitorum tendon.

answers.explanation_why: Kirschner wires are used to fixate bone fragments, particularly in fractures of smaller bones. As this patient most likely has an extensor tendon injury and shows no signs of fractures on x-ray, Kirschner wire fixation is unnecessary at this time.

While a concomitant avulsion fracture can occur in extensor tendon injuries, it only requires intraosseous suturing in select cases, as the distal interphalangeal joint is a non-weight-bearing joint and articular incongruities often heal well or are well-tolerated. Additionally, this patient's x-ray shows no signs of an associated fracture.

Buddy taping is used for minor finger or toe injuries (e.g., nondisplaced stable fractures, sprains, dislocations) if the damaged digit requires immobilization. This treatment is not the most appropriate for an acute mallet finger because it cannot ensure the ideal recovery position. In certain patients with mallet finger who need additional finger protection (e.g., athletes returning to sports, individuals with jobs that involve heavy lifting), buddy taping may be considered after initial therapy.

Surgical treatment of mallet finger is rarely required and only indicated in patients with severe fractures, subluxation of the joint, failure of conservative treatment, or in patients who cannot wear a splint (e.g., because of their profession). This patient has none of the above indications. Injuries to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon virtually always require surgical treatment. However, such injuries manifest with an inability to actively flex the distal phalanx (Jersey finger).

question_text: Paramedics are called to a 35-year-old man who has accidentally cut off his left fingertip while chopping vegetables. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. His left index finger is amputated distal to the distal interphalangeal joint at the level of the nail bed, and exposed bone is visible. There is profuse bleeding from the wound site. His ability to flex, extend, abduct, and adduct the joints is preserved and sensation is intact. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for preserving the detached fingertip prior to transporting this patient to the emergency department?
content_preview: Paramedics are called to a 35-year-old man who has accidentally cut off his left fingertip while chopping vegetables. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. His left index finger is amputated distal to the distal interphalangeal joint at the level of the nail bed, and exposed bone is visible. There is profuse bleeding from the wound site. His ability to flex, extend, abduct, and adduct the joints is preserved and sensation is intact. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for preserving the detached fingertip prior to transporting this patient to the emergency department?
hint: In complete fingertip amputations, a specific first-aid technique is recommended to preserve the amputated tissue without causing cellular damage.
learning_objective: Choose the correct method to preserve a detached fingertip prior to transport.

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with iodine in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as iodine damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in dry gauze in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: The fingertip should be wrapped in gauze, sealed in a plastic bag, and then placed on ice. However, dry gauze is not recommended because it compromises tissue integrity and decreases the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Preserve the fingertip in cooled saline water
answers.explanation_why: Although the fingertip should be kept cool during transport, direct immersion in saline water is not recommended as it may cause maceration of tissue and decrease the likelihood of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Preserve the fingertip in warm saline water
answers.explanation_why: Warm saline water is not recommended as it may cause maceration (due to direct immersion in fluid) of open tissue and encourage microbial growth in the wound (by warming), both of which would decrease the likelihood of reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze damp with saline in a sealed plastic bag placed in ice water
answers.explanation_why:
The amputated fingertip should be gently rinsed with water, wrapped in damp gauze, sealed in a watertight bag, and then placed in a bag with ice water. An amputated limb should never be placed directly on ice because of the potential for cold damage (i.e., frostbite). The aim is to preserve the finger as best as possible in order to maximize the chances of successful reattachment (replantation). The patient and their amputated fingertip should then be transported immediately to the emergency department.

Once in the emergency department, the patient's hand would be anesthetized and debrided. The decision to attempt reattachment is typically left to specialist consultation and is decided on a case-by-case basis, although it is not commonly attempted in adults.

answers.content: Place the fingertip on ice in a sealed plastic bag
answers.explanation_why: Directly placing the fingertip on ice is not recommended because of the risk of cold damage (i.e., frostbite).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with hydrogen peroxide in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as hydrogen peroxide damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with alcohol in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as alcohol damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

question_text: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of painful swelling of the right hand. There is no associated recent trauma. Physical examination shows a 3 × 3 cm area of induration that is fluctuant and warm to the touch, consistent with an abscess. The patient consents to incision and drainage of the abscess in the emergency department. Following evaluation of the patient's allergy status, a local anesthetic drug of the amide group with a particularly long duration of action is administered via subcutaneous infiltration. Which of the following local anesthetics was most likely administered?
content_preview: A 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of painful swelling of the right hand. There is no associated recent trauma. Physical examination shows a 3 × 3 cm area of induration that is fluctuant and warm to the touch, consistent with an abscess. The patient consents to incision and drainage of the abscess in the emergency department. Following evaluation of the patient's allergy status, a local anesthetic drug of the amide group with a particularly long duration of action is administered via subcutaneous infiltration. Which of the following local anesthetics was most likely administered?
hint: Anesthetic choice depends on several factors, including the duration of action required for the procedure, patient allergies, and the need for hemostasis. Many institutions use the same local anesthetic for most procedures, regardless of the duration of analgesia. However, this question asks specifically for a local anesthetic of the amide group that provides the longest duration of analgesia.
learning_objective: Recall the characteristics of amide local anesthetics.

answers.explanation_why: Bupivacaine is a long-acting, amide-type local anesthetic with an onset of ∼ 10 minutes and duration of action of 4–8 hours. Bupivacaine is commonly used for local infiltration if prolonged anesthesia or extended pain relief is required. Epinephrine is frequently combined with local anesthetics to decrease bleeding associated with procedures and to increase the duration of action of anesthesia.

Chloroprocaine is a short-acting, local anesthetic of the ester group with an onset of 6–12 minutes and duration of action of < 60 minutes. A different local anesthetic provides a longer duration of analgesia.

Procaine is a short-acting, local anesthetic of the ester group with an onset of approx. 5 minutes and duration of action of < 90 minutes. A different local anesthetic provides a longer duration of analgesia.

Lidocaine is an amide-type local anesthetic with rapid onset and intermediate duration of action of 50–120 minutes. It is the most commonly used local anesthetic; however, a different local anesthetic provides a longer duration of analgesia.
Mepivacaine is an amide-type local anesthetic with rapid onset and intermediate duration of action of 2–2.5 hours. A different local anesthetic provides a longer duration of analgesia.

Tetracaine is an intermediate to long-acting local anesthetic with rapid onset and a duration of action of 2–6 hours. However, it is an anesthetic of the ester group, not the amide group. In addition, a different local anesthetic provides a longer duration of analgesia.

question_text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of limited mobility of his right hand for 1 year. The patient states he has had difficulty actively extending his right 4^th and 5^th fingers, and despite stretching exercises, his symptoms have progressed. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been working as a mason for over 20 years. His father had similar symptoms and was treated surgically. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years and drinks 2–3 beers every day after work. His only medication is metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows skin puckering near the proximal flexor crease. There are several painless palmar nodules adjacent to the distal palmar crease. Active and passive extension of the 4^th and 5^th digits of the right hand is limited. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of limited mobility of his right hand for 1 year. The patient states he has had difficulty actively extending his right 4th and 5th fingers, and despite stretching exercises, his symptoms have progressed. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been working as a mason for over 20 years. His father had similar symptoms and was treated surgically. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years and drinks 2–3 beers every day after work. His only medication is metformin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows skin puckering near the proximal flexor crease. There are several painless palmar nodules adjacent to the distal palmar crease. Active and passive extension of the 4th and 5th digits of the right hand is limited. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Recurrent trauma to the hands (due to manual labor), diabetes mellitus, cigarette smoking, and positive family history increase the risk of developing this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize Dupuytren contracture, and recall its underlying mechanism.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's limited extension of the fingers, skin puckering, and palmar nodules suggest Dupuytren contracture. In Dupuytren contracture, overproliferation of fibroblasts and the formation of collagen nodules and cords lead to fibromatosis of the palmar fascia and restrict the extension of the affected digits (flexion contracture). The 4th and 5th digits are most commonly involved. Skin puckering near the proximal flexor crease and palmar nodules are the earliest characteristic signs. The diagnosis is usually clinical.

Conservative management (e.g., physiotherapy, hand splint) is indicated in early disease. Patients with rapidly progressing Dupuytren contracture may be treated with intralesional corticosteroids. Surgery is indicated in patients with functional disability.

images.title: Dupuytren contracture
images.description: Flexion contractures of the 5th digits are present bilaterally.These findings are consistent with Dupuytren contracture.

answers.explanation_why: Osteoarthritis can cause stiffening of the joints, especially in the morning. This stiffness, however, may wax and wane throughout the day, depending on activity level. This patient has a constant, fixed flexion contracture. Furthermore, osteoarthritis would not explain his skin puckering and nodules.

Ganglion cysts are common benign masses that develop along tendons or joints and may be asymptomatic or cause acute or chronic pain. Unlike the palmar nodules present in this patient, ganglion cysts typically occur on the back of the wrist, are commonly tender to touch, are not associated with skin puckering, and rarely cause resistance to flexion/extension; therefore, another diagnosis is more likely.

A distal ulnar nerve lesion can cause a claw hand deformity in which the patient is unable to extend the 4^th and 5^th digits. These lesions, however, are generally accompanied by numbness in the ulnar aspect of the palm, and unlike in this patient, are not associated with nodules/puckering of the skin.

Giant cell tumors of the tendon sheath are benign soft-tissue masses of the hand that are generally painless but may cause some distal numbness. Although giant cell tumors form nodules, they most commonly affect the 2^nd and 3^rd digits near the DIP joint. This patient's primary symptom is limited range of motion that affects the 4^th and 5^th digits.

Tenosynovitis can cause limited extension of the fingers and may manifest with a palpable palmar nodule. However, extension of the affected fingers and palpation of the palmar nodule are usually painful. In addition, multiple painless palmar nodules and skin puckering are not characteristic of tenosynovitis.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a progressive swelling and pain in his right ring finger for the past 2 days. The pain began while playing football, when his finger got caught in the jersey of another player who forcefully pulled away. Examination shows that the right ring finger is extended. There is pain and swelling at the distal interphalangeal joint. When the patient is asked to make a fist, his right ring finger does not flex at the distal interphalangeal joint. There is no joint laxity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a progressive swelling and pain in his right ring finger for the past 2 days. The pain began while playing football, when his finger got caught in the jersey of another player who forcefully pulled away. Examination shows that the right ring finger is extended. There is pain and swelling at the distal interphalangeal joint. When the patient is asked to make a fist, his right ring finger does not flex at the distal interphalangeal joint. There is no joint laxity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's injury is a common sports injury caused by forceful hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP).
learning_objective: Recognize rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon.

answers.content: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon at its point of insertion
answers.explanation_why: Rupture of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon, also known as “jersey finger,” is a common sports injury and most commonly affects the right ring finger. The FDP, along with the flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS), is responsible for finger flexion. The tendons from the FDP muscle run through the carpal tunnel and insert on the palmar side of the distal phalanges of each finger, whereas the FDS tendons insert on the middle phalanx. This patient's inability to flex the DIP combined with the pain over the DIP joint, which is distal to the attachment of the FDS, indicate that he has ruptured his FDP tendon.

images.title: Extensor and flexor tendons of the finger
images.description: The extensor tendons are connected by the intertendinous connection. Annular ligaments stabilize the flexor tendons, which cross one another. The superficial flexor tendons attach to the middle phalanx and the deep flexor tendons to the distal phalanx.

answers.content: Closed fracture of the distal phalanx
answers.explanation_why: The distal phalanges are the most commonly fractured bones in the hand. Distal phalanx fracture is a common sports-related injury, but it would present with pain over the phalanx itself, rather than over one of the interphalangeal joints. While deformity of the distal phalanx and nail is common with distal phalanx fractures, a specific deficit in either flexion or extension over a particular joint would be less common.

answers.content: Rupture of the extensor digitorum tendon at its point of insertion
answers.explanation_why: The extensor digitorum (ED) tendons extend the fingers of the hand. Rupture of the ED tendons leads to a pathology known as “mallet finger” or “baseball finger.” This injury often occurs when a ball hits the tip of the finger and hyperflexes the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP). Patients with this injury would be unable to extend the DIP of the affected finger and would likely have more pain on the dorsal aspect of the finger over the DIP.

images.title: Mallet finger with avulsion fracture
images.description: X-ray finger (lateral view) of a patient with inability to extend finger after traumaAn avulsion fracture of the dorsal aspect of the base of the distal phalanx (green overlay) shows intraarticular extension into the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. The injury to the extensor mechanism has resulted in a flexion deformity (indicated by arrow and lines) at the DIP joint (mallet finger).Mallet finger may be an isolated tendinous injury or may occur in combination with an avulsion fracture of the dorsal base of the distal phalanx of a finger.

answers.content: Inflammation of the flexor digitorum profundus tendon sheath
answers.explanation_why: Inflammation of the flexor tendon sheath is a condition known as “trigger finger.” The inflammation causes a stenosing tenosynovitis that leads to a locking or catching sensation during active flexion-extension activity, which can progress to the extent that the digit can only be extended through passive manipulation. Patients may also have a palpable nodule along the axis of the flexor tendon. The cause of trigger finger is unknown but may be related to repeated digital flexion.

answers.content: Slipping of the central band of the extensor digitorum tendon
answers.explanation_why: Slipping or disruption of the central band of the extensor digitorum (ED) tendon is a condition known as Boutonniere deformity. This can be caused by sharp or blunt trauma, such as jamming a finger in a door. It can also be caused by rheumatoid arthritis, in which case the inflammation of the joint space pushes the central band of the ED out of its normal anatomical position. Patients with Boutonniere deformity present with hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal joint and flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joint.

question_text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive pain and stiffness of the fingers of her right hand that is worse at the end of the day. She works as a hairdresser and has to take frequent breaks to rest her hand. Over the past 2 weeks, she has been taking ibuprofen as needed for the joint pain. Two weeks ago, she completed a course of oral antibiotics for a urinary tract infection. She has hypertension for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide. Her sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. She drinks one to two beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling, joint-line tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the right first carpometacarpal joint as well as the second and fourth distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. Discrete, hard, mildly tender swellings are palpated over the second and fourth distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for these findings?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressive pain and stiffness of the fingers of her right hand that is worse at the end of the day. She works as a hairdresser and has to take frequent breaks to rest her hand. Over the past 2 weeks, she has been taking ibuprofen as needed for the joint pain. Two weeks ago, she completed a course of oral antibiotics for a urinary tract infection. She has hypertension for which she takes hydrochlorothiazide. Her sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. She drinks one to two beers daily and occasionally more on weekends. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling, joint-line tenderness, and decreased range of motion of the right first carpometacarpal joint as well as the second and fourth distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. Discrete, hard, mildly tender swellings are palpated over the second and fourth distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for these findings?
hint: This patient presents with asymmetric oligoarthritis. The bony hard swellings on the dorsal aspect of the distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) suggest a specific etiology.
learning_objective: Recognize osteoarthritis, and recall its characteristic joint involvement.

answers.content: Monosodium urate crystal precipitation in the joints
answers.explanation_why: Gout is caused by the precipitation of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. Gout typically manifests as an acute attack of intense pain and inflammation and usually affects a single joint of the lower extremity (especially the first metatarsophalangeal joint). While she is at risk of developing gout (thiazide diuretic, alcohol consumption), her exam is typical of another disease process.

answers.content: Bacterial infection of the joint space
answers.explanation_why: Septic arthritis can cause pain, joint-line tenderness, swelling, and decreased range of motion. While it is important to consider in the differential, the onset is typically acute, and signs of local inflammation (erythema, warmth of affected joints) would be expected. This patient's physical examination suggests an alternative mechanism.

Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the joints, as seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), results in the destruction and erosion of joint cartilage. RA generally affects the small hand joints but is usually symmetric and worse with inactivity (> 30 minutes of morning stiffness). This patient does not have evidence of joint inflammation (warmth, erythema), and her physical examination is more typical of another disease process.

Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative condition characterized by pain and stiffness that worsens with activity. OA can affect any joint but frequently affects the knees, hips, and hand joints. Of the hand joints, the proximal interphalangeal and DIP joints are most commonly involved, whereas the metacarpophalangeal joints are typically spared. The Heberden nodes seen in this patient are a characteristic sign of OA.

answers.content: Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal precipitation in the joints
answers.explanation_why: Pseudogout is caused by precipitation of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints and typically manifests as recurrent episodes of acute or subacute inflammatory arthritis, usually affecting a solitary large joint. This patient lacks signs of inflammation (erythema and warmth of the joint) and her physical examination is typical of another disease process.

question_text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent pain and numbness in her right hand for 6 weeks. She has a pins-and-needles sensation that worsens at night and is relieved when she shakes her hand. She has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril. She takes over-the-counter medications for constipation. Her mother has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. She looks fatigued. Her BMI is 35 kg/m^2. Her pulse is 57/min and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is a normal range of motion in the wrists and digits. Sensation in the right thumb and index finger is decreased to light touch. There is no thenar muscle atrophy. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ throughout and there is mild nonpitting edema in the legs. This patient is most likely to benefit from which of the following treatments?
content_preview: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent pain and numbness in her right hand for 6 weeks. She has a pins-and-needles sensation that worsens at night and is relieved when she shakes her hand. She has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril. She takes over-the-counter medications for constipation. Her mother has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. She looks fatigued. Her BMI is 35 kg/m2. Her pulse is 57/min and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is a normal range of motion in the wrists and digits. Sensation in the right thumb and index finger is decreased to light touch. There is no thenar muscle atrophy. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ throughout and there is mild nonpitting edema in the legs. This patient is most likely to benefit from which of the following treatments?
hint: This patient's elevated BMI, constipation, nonpitting edema, and carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) are characteristic of a specific disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize hypothyroidism, and choose the appropriate treatment for its manifestations.

answers.explanation_why: This patient presents with classic signs of hypothyroidism: constipation, fatigue, bradycardia, hyporeflexia, and nonpitting lower limb edema. Although the precise pathophysiology is unknown, it is assumed that excess deposition of glycosaminoglycans, hyaluronic acid, and mucopolysaccharides in hypothyroidism causes myxedema. These characteristic deposits can cause compression of the carpal tunnel. Treatment with a thyroid hormone replacement (i.e., levothyroxine) should cause a return to a euthyroid state and improvement of symptoms within several weeks.

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite primarily used as a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) for rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The precise pathophysiology of CTS due to RA is uncertain, but it is thought to be due to increased carpal tunnel pressure caused by inflammation and edema. Although patients with RA typically report joint pain (like the knee pain in this patient), the metacarpophalangeal, and proximal interphalangeal joints are more commonly involved. Furthermore, patients with RA typically report morning stiffness.

images.title: Distribution of joint involvement in rheumatoid arthritis of the hand
images.description: Symmetrical swelling of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints.

answers.explanation_why: NSAIDs are not generally recommended for the management of CTS. This patient is most likely to benefit from treatment of their underlying condition.

Surgical treatment is usually indicated for patients who have features of severe CTS (e.g., weakness in the median nerve distribution, thenar atrophy) or who do not respond to conservative treatment. This patient shows no signs of severe CTS and is most likely to benefit from initial treatment of her underlying condition.

images.title: Surgical management of carpal tunnel syndrome
images.description:
Intraoperative palmar view of the wristThe incision is held open by a self-retaining retractor (distal; top of image) and a hook-shaped retractor (proximal; bottom of image). The transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum of the hand) has been surgically divided to decompress the median nerve. The thenar part of the split transverse carpal ligament (blue overlay) and the median nerve (green overlay) are visible in the wound.
Next to the median nerve, the median artery (red overlay) can be seen (this usually regresses before birth but may persist). Sources differ widely regarding the frequency of a persisting palmar median artery (1.5% to 50%), and it has been suggested that its presence may be associated with an increased risk of carpal tunnel syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Steroid therapy (e.g., prednisone therapy) can be effective in patients who only experience mild to moderate symptoms of CTS. However, steroid therapy has not been studied in cases in which CTS developed secondary to an underlying condition. The underlying cause should be treated first. Furthermore, steroids are usually administered as an injection, while oral steroids are a second-line treatment for those who decline injection therapy.

question_text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a friend after he was found lying unconscious outside his front door. The friend reports that they were “pretty drunk” the previous night, and she had dropped her friend off at his home and driven off. When she came back in the morning, she found him passed out on the ground next to the doorstep. On arrival, he is conscious and cooperative. He reports feeling cold, with severe pain in his hands and face. He remembers having lost his gloves last night. His rectal temperature is 35.2°C (95.3°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 124/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensations over the distal fingers, which are cold to touch. The skin over the distal phalanges is cyanotic, hard, waxy, and tender, with surrounding edema. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by a friend after he was found lying unconscious outside his front door. The friend reports that they were “pretty drunk” the previous night, and she had dropped her friend off at his home and driven off. When she came back in the morning, she found him passed out on the ground next to the doorstep. On arrival, he is conscious and cooperative. He reports feeling cold, with severe pain in his hands and face. He remembers having lost his gloves last night. His rectal temperature is 35.2°C (95.3°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 124/58 mm Hg. Examination shows decreased sensations over the distal fingers, which are cold to touch. The skin over the distal phalanges is cyanotic, hard, waxy, and tender, with surrounding edema. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's hands show signs of frostbite following prolonged exposure to the cold.
learning_objective: Recognize frostbite, and choose the most appropriate initial treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Debridement may be indicated in the management of frostbite. While this patient's hands show features of frostbite, surgical treatment with debridement or amputation should not be performed until all nonviable tissue becomes clearly demarcated, a process that usually takes 3–4 weeks.

answers.content: Intra-arterial administration of tissue plasminogen activator
answers.explanation_why: Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), in combination with heparin, is indicated in the treatment of frostbite in patients without contraindications for anticoagulation therapy. tPA acts to prevent vascular thrombosis in frostbitten tissue, but it is usually reserved for patients at high risk for a life-altering amputation. This patient has cyanosis of the distal phalanges only, which will likely be treated with a soft-tissue amputation, or no amputation at all. A different step in management is more urgent at this time.

Intravenous administration of warmed crystalloid is indicated to treat individuals with severe hypothermia (core body temperature < 28°C (< 82°F)). Since this patient is only borderline hypothermic, passive rewarming measures (e.g., removing wet clothing, warm room) are sufficient and IV crystalloid infusion is not required.

Extracorporeal blood rewarming may be used to manage individuals with severe hypothermia (core body temperature < 28°C (< 82°F)). While it is the most effective method of active rewarming, it is an invasive procedure associated with a number of risks (e.g., hemorrhages, stroke) and is reserved for management of the most severe cases. This patient would benefit from passive rewarming measures (e.g., warm clothing, blankets) but does not require treatment for severe hypothermia.

In an individual with frostbite, treatment with intravenous antibiotics and sterile dressings is indicated to manage bacterial superinfections. Since this patient shows no signs of infection (e.g., localized swelling, erythema, fever, leukocytosis), antibiotic treatment is not required.

answers.content: Immersion of affected extremities in warm water
answers.explanation_why:
In patients with suspected frostbite, active rewarming of the affected extremity is indicated to avoid further tissue damage. The affected extremity should be immersed in a warm (preferably 37–39°C), circulating water bath. Passive rewarming is also helpful (especially in patients with mild hypothermia) and includes removing any wet clothes, covering with blankets, and increasing the temperature of the room.

In patients with concomitant moderate-to-severe hypothermia, treatment of hypothermia should take priority because it can be acutely life-threatening. The trunk should be warmed prior to the extremities, as peripheral vasodilation may lead to a return of cold blood to the heart, which increases the risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain in her right thumb and wrist that radiates to her elbow. It is worse when she holds her 7-month-old son and improves with the use of an ice pack. Six months ago, she slipped on a wet floor and fell on her right outstretched hand. Her mother takes methotrexate for chronic joint pain. The patient takes ibuprofen as needed for her current symptoms. Examination of the right-hand shows tenderness over the radial styloid with swelling but no redness. There is no crepitus. Grasping her right thumb and exerting longitudinal traction toward the ulnar side elicits pain. Range of motion of the finger joints is normal. There is no swelling, redness, or tenderness of any other joints. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain in her right thumb and wrist that radiates to her elbow. It is worse when she holds her 7-month-old son and improves with the use of an ice pack. Six months ago, she slipped on a wet floor and fell on her right outstretched hand. Her mother takes methotrexate for chronic joint pain. The patient takes ibuprofen as needed for her current symptoms. Examination of the right-hand shows tenderness over the radial styloid with swelling but no redness. There is no crepitus. Grasping her right thumb and exerting longitudinal traction toward the ulnar side elicits pain. Range of motion of the finger joints is normal. There is no swelling, redness, or tenderness of any other joints. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A positive Finkelstein test is pathognomonic for this patient's condition.

answers.explanation_why: Skier's thumb, also known as gamekeeper's thumb, is a result of injury to the ulnar-sided collateral ligament of the thumb. This condition is usually caused by a fall on the thumb and manifests with pain and swelling over the MCP joint of the thumb. The examination would show laxity of the thumb's MCP joint on the ulnar side (i.e., hyperabduction) and a weak pinch grip. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a different condition.

A boutonniere deformity can occur secondary to trauma or rheumatoid arthritis. It is characterized by injury to the extensor mechanism of the finger and classically manifests with hyperextension of the DIP and flexion of the PIP. Boutonniere deformity of the thumb is seen as hyperextension of the interphalangeal joint. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a different condition.

images.title: Boutonniere deformity
images.description: Characteristic appearance of the ring finger with flexed PIP and hyperextended DIP jointsThis condition is the result of injury to or slippage of the central band of the extensor digitorum, usually caused by trauma (e.g., sports injury) or chronic inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis.

answers.explanation_why: De Quervain tenosynovitis is a common cause of wrist pain in adults and is more common in women, particularly in new mothers due to the repeated strain of lifting the baby. While the exact pathophysiology is unknown, it is attributed to repetitive activities involving postures that maintain the thumb in extension and abduction. Diagnosis of this tendinopathy is established by the physical exam findings of pain over the radial styloid and a positive Finkelstein test. Treatment is usually conservative and involves oral NSAIDs, rest, splinting, and corticosteroid injections.

images.title: Finkelstein test
images.description: The examiner holds the patient's thumb in flexion and applies ulnar deviation to the wrist. The test is positive if the patient feels a sharp pain over the first extensor tendon compartment (along the distal radius). This finding is pathognomonic for de Quervain tenosynovitis.

answers.explanation_why: Swan neck deformity is typically seen in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis that affects the finger joints. The examination would show hyperflexion of the DIP and hyperextension of the PIP. Swan neck deformity of the thumb is seen as hyperflexion of the interphalangeal joint and hyperextension of the MCP. This patient has none of these clinical features.

images.title: Swan neck deformity
images.description: Proximal interphalangeal joint hyperextension and distal interphalangeal joint flexion

answers.explanation_why: Mallet finger is a closed extensor tendon injury typically caused by a sudden hyperflexion of the DIP (forced flexion) usually from a direct blow to the tip of the finger (e.g., baseball hitting the tip of the finger). The examination would show a loss of extension of the DIP of the affected finger, with the DIP remaining in a flexed position at rest. This patient has none of these clinical features.

images.title: Mallet finger
images.description: Right middle finger with extended PIP and flexed DIP jointsThis condition results from sudden forced hyperflexion of the DIP joint while the digit is extended (particularly common in sports such as basketball and baseball), which causes rupture or avulsion of the extensor digitorum tendon.

answers.explanation_why: Carpal tunnel syndrome is characterized by sensorimotor disturbances (i.e, paresthesia, weakness) in the area of the hand innervated by the median nerve (i.e., the thumb, index, middle, radial border of the ring finger). The paresthesia can be elicited by passively flexing the wrist (positive Phalen sign). The symptoms this patient presents with are inconsistent with a diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome.

Stenosing tenosynovitis, also called trigger finger, usually affects patients in their 5^th or 6^th decade, and females are more commonly affected. Although the thumb is frequently affected, the patient would typically present with painful locking of finger in a flexed position which is suddenly relieved by a snap/pop on extension. The examination would show tenderness and a palpable nodule at the base of the metacarpophalangeal joint. This patient's clinical features are consistent with a different condition.

question_text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 30 minutes after she was bitten by her neighbor's cat. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She received all recommended immunizations during childhood but has not received any since then. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows four deep puncture wounds on the thenar eminence of the right hand. There is mild swelling but no erythema. There is normal range of motion of her right thumb and wrist. The wound is cleaned with povidone-iodine and irrigated with saline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 30 minutes after she was bitten by her neighbor's cat. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She received all recommended immunizations during childhood but has not received any since then. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows four deep puncture wounds on the thenar eminence of the right hand. There is mild swelling but no erythema. There is normal range of motion of her right thumb and wrist. The wound is cleaned with povidone-iodine and irrigated with saline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Patients with deep puncture wounds (extending through the epidermis) from cat bites are at an increased risk of infection.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for a deep puncture wound from a cat bite.

answers.explanation_why: Wound culture can be performed to identify the bacteria responsible for an infection, which would ensure the selection of an appropriate antibiotic. However, since this patient's wound does not appear infected (e.g., no purulent drainage, surrounding erythema, warmth, or necrotic tissue), wound culture is not indicated.

Antibiotic prophylaxis should be provided following a deep puncture wound from a cat bite in order to prevent abscess formation and serious infections (e.g., osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, infectious tenosynovitis, bacteremia). Amoxicillin-clavulanate is the first-line treatment as it is effective against most bacteria present in feline saliva, including Pasteurella multocida. In addition to antibiotics, the wound should be thoroughly irrigated with saline and left open to allow drainage and healing by secondary intention.

Bite wounds should be left open to heal by secondary intention to allow spontaneous drainage and prevent deep infection. Surgical wound closure is only recommended for bite wounds that are large and/or disfiguring (e.g., wounds of the face). This patient's wounds do not meet the criteria for surgical closure and should be left open.

Bite wounds from cats carry a significant risk of infection. Given the potentially serious complications (e.g., abscess, osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, infectious tenosynovitis), reassurance alone is not appropriate.

answers.content: Close the wound with cyanoacrylate tissue adhesive
answers.explanation_why: Tissue adhesive can be considered in the closure of small, clean skin lacerations. However, tissue adhesive should be avoided in wounds in highly mobile areas, such as on the hands or over joints (as in this patient). In addition, other than in special circumstances (e.g., large wounds, cosmetic concerns, facial wounds), bite wounds should generally be left open to heal by secondary intention and allow spontaneous drainage, which prevents infection.

The rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin should be given to any patient bitten by an animal that is potentially rabies-infected. Animal types of concern include bats, raccoons, skunks, foxes, and unvaccinated domestic animals. In the case of a bite from an unvaccinated pet, a 10 day observation period is recommended. Postexposure prophylaxis is only recommended if the animal develops signs of rabies (e.g., agitation, aggression, seizures, paralysis) within that time.

answers.content: Administer tetanus toxoid and tetanus IV immunoglobulin
answers.explanation_why: Bite wounds are considered tetanus-prone, and tetanus toxoid vaccine should be given if the patient's last booster was more than 5 years ago (as is likely in this patient). However, tetanus immunoglobulin is only indicated if patients have had less than three tetanus toxoid doses. This patient received all childhood immunizations (which typically include three doses of the tetanus vaccine). Therefore, she does not require tetanus immunoglobulin.

Bite wounds from cats carry a significant risk of infection with Pasteurella multocida, a bacteria commonly found in feline oral flora. While cephalexin is effective against some gram-negative bacteria, it is less effective against P. multocida and is not indicated for this type of injury.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of recurrent thumb pain that worsens with exposure to cold temperatures. Examination shows a 6-mm, blue-red papule under the left thumbnail. The overlying area is extremely tender to palpation. The thumbnail is slightly pitted and cracked. This lesion most likely developed from which of the following types of cells?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of recurrent thumb pain that worsens with exposure to cold temperatures. Examination shows a 6-mm, blue-red papule under the left thumbnail. The overlying area is extremely tender to palpation. The thumbnail is slightly pitted and cracked. This lesion most likely developed from which of the following types of cells?
hint: This patient's tender blue-red lesion under the left thumbnail, with pain that worsens with exposure to cold temperatures, suggests a glomus tumor.
learning_objective: Recognize a glomus tumor, and recall its cell of origin.

answers.explanation_why: Dysplastic melanocytes are characteristic of a dysplastic nevus or melanoma. These lesions can uncommonly develop under the nail (e.g., acral lentiginous melanoma) but are not typically painful or sensitive to cold temperatures.

images.title: Atypical nevus
images.description: An asymmetric, pigmented lesion with irregular borders and color variegation is visible over the left little finger.These are characteristic features of an atypical nevus.

answers.explanation_why: Hemangiomas are comprised of capillary endothelial cells. Cherry hemangiomas in adults commonly develop on the trunk and upper extremities as multiple, painless, cherry-red, dome-shaped papules; they are not typically found under the nail.
answers.explanation_but: Infantile hemangiomas are also comprised of capillary endothelial cells and may manifest as blue-red papules on the fingers. They are typically not painful and usually involute within a few years.

images.title: Capillary hemangioma of the skin (cherry angioma)
images.description: Multiple well-demarcated cherry-red papules are distributed on the skin.This appearance is characteristic of cherry angiomas.

answers.explanation_why:
Glomus tumors are benign tumors that arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus body, which is involved in dermal thermoregulation. These tumors classically manifest as small (< 2 cm), solitary, painful, blue-red papules or nodules located on the hand, foot, or under the nails in patients 20–40 years of age. The pain associated with glomus tumors is characteristically paroxysmal, severe, and is exacerbated by cold.

Diagnosis is typically clinical and confirmed by histopathologic examination. Treatment involves surgical excision.

images.title: Glomus tumor
images.description: A solitary vascularized subcutaneous nodule is visible on the pulp of the little finger of the left hand.

answers.explanation_why: Hyperpigmented fibroblasts are characteristic of a dermatofibroma, which typically manifests as an asymptomatic, brown papule on the lower extremities with characteristic central dimpling when pinched (dimple sign); they are not typically found under the nail.

images.title: Dermatofibroma
images.description: A solitary, pigmented, firm circular lesion is visible. Upon pinching of the lesion, the overlaying skin retracts inwards (dimple sign).This appearance is suggestive of a dermatofibroma, which usually manifests as a nodule.

answers.explanation_why: Abnormal growth of basal epidermal cells can cause basal cell carcinomas (BCC), which can uncommonly manifest as a pigmented lesion. However, BCCs typically develop in older individuals with an extensive history of sun exposure as a nodular, nontender lesion with a rolled border and central ulceration. BCCs are not typically found under the nail and they are not associated with cold sensitivity.

images.title: Pigmented basal cell carcinoma
images.description: A red-brown plaque with nodules is visible on an area of skin from the patient's upper thigh. The lesion exhibits both irregular (left) and well-defined borders (right). The surface of the lesion is shiny. Brown melanin pigmentation can also be seen.

question_text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a motorcycle collision. Physical examination shows a deep laceration on the volar surface of the distal left forearm. Neurological examination shows loss of abduction and opposition of the left thumb. The radial and ulnar pulses are palpable. Based on these findings, which of the following nerves is most likely injured in this patient?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a motorcycle collision. Physical examination shows a deep laceration on the volar surface of the distal left forearm. Neurological examination shows loss of abduction and opposition of the left thumb. The radial and ulnar pulses are palpable. Based on these findings, which of the following nerves is most likely injured in this patient?
hint: If this same nerve were injured more proximally (e.g., at or above the elbow), examination would show the hand of benediction sign.

answers.explanation_why: The posterior interosseous nerve is a terminal branch of the radial nerve located deep in the dorsal forearm, making it very unlikely to be injured by a volar laceration. Injury to this nerve typically causes extension deficits at the wrist and fingers. Injury to the posterior interosseous nerve does not affect abduction or opposition of the thumb.

The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor as well as the skin overlying the lateral shoulder. Injury to this nerve classically occurs with anterior shoulder dislocations or fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus and causes weak arm abduction and a characteristically flattened shoulder. Injury to the axillary nerve does not affect the thumb.

The radial nerve courses along the dorsal aspect of the forearm and thus is very unlikely to be injured by a volar laceration. Patients with radial nerve injuries typically have extension deficits at the elbow, wrist, and fingers. Injury to the radial nerve does not affect abduction or opposition of the thumb.

Laceration of the median nerve at the wrist causes loss of thumb abduction and opposition, as seen in this patient. Additional deficits include reduced or absent sensation in the thumb, index, middle, and radial-sided ring fingers. The laceration could be through the median nerve proper or through the recurrent branch of the median nerve. The presence of sensory disturbances would be the determining factor, as the recurrent branch solely provides motor innervation.

images.title: Proximal and distal median nerve lesions
images.description: AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

answers.explanation_why: The musculocutaneous nerve is not typically affected by distal forearm injuries. Injury to this nerve (e.g., from upper trunk compression) causes loss of forearm flexion and supination as well as loss of sensation over the lateral forearm. Injury to the musculocutaneous nerve does not affect abduction or opposition of the thumb.

Distal injuries to the ulnar nerve typically cause sensory deficits in the ulnar-sided ring and small fingers. Motor deficits manifest with hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the distal interphalangeal joints and proximal interphalangeal joints when the patient is asked to make a fist (ulnar claw). Injury to the ulnar nerve does not affect the thumb.

question_text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of right wrist pain after a fall from a ladder. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength and tenderness between the tendons of extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis. X-ray of the right wrist shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of right wrist pain after a fall from a ladder. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength and tenderness between the tendons of extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis. X-ray of the right wrist shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
hint: The region between the tendons of extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis is called the anatomical snuff box.
learning_objective: Recognize scaphoid fracture, and recall its complications.

answers.content: Paralysis of the abductor pollicis brevis muscle
answers.explanation_why: Paralysis of the abductor pollicis brevis is a feature of median nerve palsy, which can occur following a fall on the hand due to compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel by a dislocated lunate. However, lunate dislocation would cause swelling in the wrist with restriction of the range of motion, and the dislocated lunate would be clearly visible on x-ray. This patient with pain in the anatomical snuffbox and a normal initial x-ray most likely has a different injury.

images.title: Lunate dislocation and radial styloid fracture
images.description: X-ray wrist (left: PA view; right: lateral view)The lunate (dashed outline) is displaced and rotated volarly, creating the classic triangular piece-of-pie sign of lunate dislocation on the PA view. Widening of the scapholunate interval (yellow overlay) is also seen. Volar angulation and displacement of the lunate are also seen on the lateral view, producing the spilled teacup appearance.A displaced radial styloid fracture (green overlay and red line) is also visible.

answers.content: Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid bone
answers.explanation_why: Decreased grip strength with pain in the anatomical snuffbox suggests a scaphoid fracture, which is typically caused by falling onto an outstretched hand. The scaphoid bone, which is one of the carpal bones that forms the radiocarpal joint, receives its blood supply from an end artery that runs in a distal to proximal direction. A fracture of the scaphoid can damage this branch of the radial artery and cause avascular necrosis of the proximal segment. Avascular necrosis of the scaphoid increases the risk of osteoarthritis of the radiocarpal joint. The initial x-ray in the case of scaphoid fracture can be normal. Therefore, patients with a normal x-ray should be followed up with a repeat x-ray after approx. 2 weeks or an MRI if a scaphoid fracture is strongly suspected.

images.title: Arterial blood supply of the scaphoid bone
images.description:
The scaphoid is supplied primarily by branches of the radial artery. As illustrated here, the superficial palmar branch penetrates the bone from the palmar side and the dorsal carpal branch from the dorsal side, both at the distal pole. There may, however, be significant variation, both in which radial branches are the principal contributors and in their branching patterns.

Because the arterial blood supply of the scaphoid flows from the distal pole to the proximal pole, more proximal scaphoid fractures are at higher risk of nonunion and avascular necrosis.

answers.explanation_why: Avascular necrosis leading to the collapse of the lunate is seen in Kienbock disease, a condition that is associated with repetitive impact to the hand (e.g., playing volleyball). This patient with pain in the anatomic snuff box after acute trauma is most likely to develop avascular necrosis of the scaphoid, not the lunate.

Hypesthesia of the hypothenar eminence is a feature of ulnar nerve palsy, which can occur following a fall on the hand due to compression of the ulnar nerve by a fractured hook of hamate. Hook of hamate fractures can cause decreased grip strength, and the initial wrist x-ray can be normal in anteroposterior and lateral views. However, patients with a hook of hamate fracture would have tenderness on the palmar surface of the hand at the site of the hamate. This patient with pain in the anatomical snuffbox (dorsal surface of the hand) most likely has a different injury.

images.title: Distal row of carpal bones
images.description: The carpal bones are numbered consecutively, with the distal row highlighted in blue.

answers.explanation_why: Risk factors for contraction of the palmar aponeurosis (Dupuytren contracture) are repetitive trauma, cigarette smoking, heavy alcohol use, diabetes mellitus, and autoimmune diseases. This patient's injury is not a risk factor for Dupuytren contracture.

question_text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent tingling of his hand. He is an avid cyclist and has recently started training for a cycle marathon. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength in the right hand and wasting of the hypothenar eminence. On asking the patient to grasp a piece of paper between his right thumb and right index finger in the first web space, there is hyperflexion of the right thumb interphalangeal joint. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
content_preview: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent tingling of his hand. He is an avid cyclist and has recently started training for a cycle marathon. Physical examination shows decreased grip strength in the right hand and wasting of the hypothenar eminence. On asking the patient to grasp a piece of paper between his right thumb and right index finger in the first web space, there is hyperflexion of the right thumb interphalangeal joint. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
hint: A positive Froment sign (hyperflexion of the thumb due to paralysis of the adductor pollicis and unopposed action of flexor pollicis longus) and wasting of the hypothenar eminence are suggestive of ulnar nerve entrapment.
learning_objective: Recognize ulnar nerve entrapment at Guyon canal, and recall its associated hand muscle dysfunctions.

answers.content: Loss of sensation over dorsal aspect of 1^st web space
answers.explanation_why: Sensation in the dorsal web space between the thumb and index finger is often examined to assess intact radial nerve sensation. It would not be affected by this patient's ulnar nerve compression.

images.title: Sensory innervation areas of the peripheral nerves (arm, dorsal view)

answers.content: Inability to flex the index finger at the interphalangeal joints
answers.explanation_why: Flexion of the index finger at either the proximal or distal interphalangeal joints requires the action of the flexor digitorum superficialis (proximal joint) or flexor digitorum profundus (proximal and distal joints). The flexor digitorum superficialis and the lateral aspect of the flexor digitorium profundus (which flexes the index and middle finger) are innervated by the median nerve and would be unaffected by this patient's ulnar nerve compression.

answers.content: Loss of sensation over the dorsum of the medial half of the hand
answers.explanation_why: The dorsum of the medial half of the hand (ring and small fingers) is innervated by the dorsal cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve, which arises in the forearm proximal to the passage of the ulnar nerve through Guyon canal. As this patient exhibits nerve compression at the level of Guyon canal, the sensory innervation to the medial half of the dorsum of the hand will remain intact.

answers.content: Inability to extend the ring finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint
answers.explanation_why: Extension of the ring finger at the metacarpophalangeal joint is mediated by the action of the extensor digitorum muscle, which is innervated by the radial nerve. The function of this muscle would not be affected by ulnar nerve compression.

answers.content: Inability to extend the little finger at the proximal interphalangeal joints
answers.explanation_why:
This patient's physical examination is suggestive of long-term ulnar nerve compression at the level of Guyon canal (Guyon canal syndrome), which is common in avid cyclists due to long-term pressure of the wrist against bike handlebars. This compression disrupts innervation to the ulnar innervated intrinsic hand muscles, including the lumbricals, which are responsible for little finger extension at the proximal interphalangeal joint. Additional physical exam findings typically seen in this syndrome include numbness of the palmar surface of the small and ring fingers.

While splinting, cortisone injections, and NSAIDs may improve this patient's complaints, surgical release of the volar carpal ligament is required in refractory cases.

images.title: Ulnar nerve neuropathy
images.description:
Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4^th and 5^th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1^st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3^rd and 4^th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingersProximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

question_text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a mass on his left wrist. He reports that the mass has gradually increased in size since he first noticed it 6 months ago. He has no pain, numbness, or weakness in the left hand. There is no history of previous hand trauma. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Family history is remarkable for gout in his father. The patient works as a carpenter. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 3-cm nontender, mobile, fluctuant mass on the dorsum of the wrist; a photograph of the left hand is shown. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a well-defined, anechoic mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a mass on his left wrist. He reports that the mass has gradually increased in size since he first noticed it 6 months ago. He has no pain, numbness, or weakness in the left hand. There is no history of previous hand trauma. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Family history is remarkable for gout in his father. The patient works as a carpenter. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 3-cm nontender, mobile, fluctuant mass on the dorsum of the wrist; a photograph of the left hand is shown. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a well-defined, anechoic mass. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's asymptomatic mass at the dorsal wrist that is anechoic on ultrasonography is consistent with a ganglion cyst, the most common soft tissue tumor of the hand.
learning_objective: Recognize a ganglion cyst, and choose the most appropriate management for an asymptomatic presentation.

answers.explanation_why: Reassurance and observation is the preferred management approach for asymptomatic ganglion cysts, because most resolve spontaneously within a year. Symptomatic cysts (e.g., due to weakness, paresthesia, pain) can be aspirated; however, 50% of ganglion cysts that are aspirated will most likely recur within a year. Surgery may be performed for patients who experience persistent or recurrent symptoms despite initial nonsurgical management, or who experience severe pain or significant limitation in daily activities.

Colchicine therapy is used in the initial treatment of tophaceous gout (before initiation of urate-lowering therapy), which typically manifests as painless masses at various joints. Tophaceous gout masses are hard, nonfluctuant, and typically occur in patients with signs of chronic gout (e.g., joint deformities, uric acid nephrolithiasis).

A biopsy is indicated to rule out malignancy (e.g., synovial sarcoma) in tissue masses that increase in size. Ultrasound of a malignant mass would show a heterogeneous hypoechoic mass rather than a well-defined and anechoic mass. Moreover, malignancy in the hand, such as synovial sarcoma, is much less common than a ganglion cyst.

Intralesional triamcinolone injection is the preferred treatment for epidermoid cysts, which manifest as an asymptomatic mobile mass. Epidermoid cysts are nonfluctuant, small, and hard nodules that are usually < 1 cm in size, whereas this patient has a 3 cm fluctuant mass.

Incision and drainage is the preferred treatment for an abscess, which typically manifests as a fluctuant mass. However, abscesses develop acutely, whereas this patient's lesion developed over the course of 6 months. Moreover, an abscess typically also causes pain, erythema, warmth, and/or fever.

images.title: Ganglion cyst
images.description: A round, swollen nodule can be seen at the dorsal wrist.This appearance is characteristic of a ganglion cyst.
