question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a dark red mass on his left thumb. The lesion has rapidly increased in size over the past 2 months. It is not painful, but the lesion bled profusely once when he accidentally bumped his hand on a desk. About 6 months ago, his cat scratched him on the left thumb. He has asthma well controlled with inhaled beclomethasone and albuterol. He is otherwise healthy and receives no other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left upper extremity shows a solitary 2-cm lesion on the interphalangeal joint of the thumb; a photograph of the lesion is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a dark red mass on his left thumb. The lesion has rapidly increased in size over the past 2 months. It is not painful, but the lesion bled profusely once when he accidentally bumped his hand on a desk. About 6 months ago, his cat scratched him on the left thumb. He has asthma well controlled with inhaled beclomethasone and albuterol. He is otherwise healthy and receives no other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left upper extremity shows a solitary 2-cm lesion on the interphalangeal joint of the thumb; a photograph of the lesion is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This condition typically develops following skin trauma.

answers.explanation_why: A cherry hemangioma can manifest as a painless, red lesion that may bleed profusely after trauma. However, cherry hemangiomas are usually seen in adults older than 30 years of age and rarely occur on the hands. Moreover, multiple, smaller (0.1–0.4 cm) lesions rather than a single nodule are typically seen.

images.title: Capillary hemangioma of the skin (cherry angioma)
images.description: Multiple well-demarcated cherry-red papules are distributed on the skin.This appearance is characteristic of cherry angiomas.

answers.explanation_why: Pyogenic granuloma (PG) is a benign, vascular tumor characterized by rapid growth and a tendency to bleed profusely after minor trauma. PG typically manifests as a painless, red papule or nodule and often develops at sites of skin injury on the face or hands, as seen here. The exact cause is unknown. Young men and pregnant women are commonly affected. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings but a histopathological confirmation can help to rule out malignant tumors. Surgical excision is the preferred method of treatment because it reduces the recurrence rate. Other methods of treatment include laser therapy, cryotherapy, intralesional steroid injections, and topical therapies (e.g., beta-blockers).

A glomus tumor can manifest as a red-purple nodule on the fingers. However, glomus tumors are typically located on the nail bed or the palm and are associated with severe paroxysmal pain, tenderness, and cold sensitivity. Furthermore, a glomus tumor does not usually bleed following minor trauma or develop at the site of an injury.

images.title: Glomus tumor
images.description: A solitary vascularized subcutaneous nodule is visible on the pulp of the little finger of the left hand.

answers.explanation_why: Bacillary angiomatosis is typically transmitted by cat scratches and patients can present with a solitary, red nodule that bleeds easily. However, patients with bacillary angiomatosis usually present with constitutional symptoms, such as fever, chills, and malaise. Moreover, bacillary angiomatosis is characteristically seen in immunocompromised patients (especially patients with HIV infection and a CD4 count < 100/mm^3).

images.title: Bacillary angiomatosis
images.description: Two angioma-like lesions with a surrounding erythematous halo are visible.This immunocompromised patient was diagnosed with bacillary angiomatosis due to Bartonella quintana.

answers.explanation_why: Kaposi sarcoma can manifest with a painless, red-brown nodule. However, multiple lesions on the lower legs, chest, and/or mucous membranes are typically seen. Moreover, Kaposi sarcoma is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., individuals with HIV, organ transplant recipients) and does not usually lead to profuse bleeding following minor trauma.

images.title: Kaposi sarcoma on skin
images.description: A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

answers.explanation_why: A keloid scar typically develops at the site of a wound 3–12 months after the injury, similar to what is seen in this patient, who was scratched by a cat 6 months ago. However, a keloid scar consists of brownish-red scar tissue with a claw-like appearance that grows beyond the boundaries of the injury, unlike what is seen here. Furthermore, in contrast to this patient's presentation, a keloid scar is usually painful, pruritic, and does not bleed following minor trauma.

images.title: Earlobe keloid
images.description: The left earlobe (lobule) bears a well-defined lesion that extends well beyond the boundary of the initial defect (most likely an ear piercing).

images.title: Pyogenic granuloma
images.description: Photograph of the left thumbA 2-3 cm dark red, round, shiny mass can be seen at the interphalangeal joint.This appearance is characteristic of a pyogenic granuloma.

question_text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of pain in her right index finger. She does not recall injuring her finger but the pain has become progressively worse and over the past 4 days, the painful area has become slightly swollen and red. She works as a bartender at a local bar. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/75 mm Hg. Examination of the right index finger shows an erythematous, swollen, and tender lateral nail fold; the nail plate and nail bed appear normal. When light pressure is applied to the volar aspect of the fingertip, a well-demarcated, fluctuating area of blanching appears in the lateral nail fold. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of pain in her right index finger. She does not recall injuring her finger but the pain has become progressively worse and over the past 4 days, the painful area has become slightly swollen and red. She works as a bartender at a local bar. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 74/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/75 mm Hg. Examination of the right index finger shows an erythematous, swollen, and tender lateral nail fold; the nail plate and nail bed appear normal. When light pressure is applied to the volar aspect of the fingertip, a well-demarcated, fluctuating area of blanching appears in the lateral nail fold. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's clinical features and the duration of symptoms (< 6 weeks) are consistent with acute paronychia. A positive digital pressure test indicates an abscess.
learning_objective: Recognize acute paronychia with abscess, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.content: Soaks with warm water and 1% acetic acid
answers.explanation_why: Soaks with warm water and 1% acetic acid are appropriate first-line therapy for patients with acute paronychia who do not have an abscess. This patient's positive digital pressure test indicates an abscess, which warrants another treatment modality.

Incision and drainage (I&D) is the treatment of choice for acute paronychia if an abscess is present. Antibiotic therapy following I&D is only warranted in patients with immunosuppression or overlying cellulitis. If an abscess is not present, management of acute paronychia includes elevation, soaking the affected digit in warm water 2–4 times daily, and topical antibiotics (e.g., mupirocin). Complications of this infection include development of felon, osteomyelitis, or chronic paronychia.

Risk factors for acute paronychia include professions involving manual labor in which trauma to the nail folds or exposure to moisture may occur (such as a bartender).

images.title: Paronychia
images.description: Characteristic finding of paronychia: Periungual erythema and pus lateral to the nail.

answers.explanation_why: Eponychial marsupialization is a surgical technique that is sometimes used to treat chronic paronychia. Eponychial marsupialization is not used in the treatment of acute paronychia and even in patients with chronic paronychia, this procedure is not a recommended first-line therapy.

Topical antibiotics (e.g., mupirocin) are an appropriate first-line therapy and topical corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) are an appropriate adjunctive therapy for patients with acute paronychia without abscess. This patient's positive digital pressure test indicates an abscess, which warrants another treatment modality.

Oral antibiotic therapy (e.g., dicloxacillin, cephalexin, amoxicillin/clavulanate) is only indicated for the treatment of acute paronychia if patients do not respond to topical therapy alone, have overlying cellulitis, or are immunocompromised.
